original_theorem:
Suppose that  $K$ is a bounded set with zero content and $\epsilon,$
$\rho>0.$  Then there are cubes $C_1,$ $C_2,$ \dots$,$
$C_r$ with edge lengths
$<\rho$ such that  $C_j\cap K\ne\emptyset,$ $1\le j\le r,$
\begin{equation}\label{eq:7.3.5}
K\subset\bigcup_{j=1}^r C_j,
\end{equation}
and
$$
\sum_{j=1}^r V(C_j)<\epsilon.
$$
theorem_translation:
```lean4
theorem cubes_cover_of_bounded_content_zero {ι : Type*} [Fintype ι] {K : Set (ι → ℝ)} {ε ρ : ℝ}
    (hK_bounded : Bornology.IsBounded K) (hK_content_zero : MeasureTheory.Content.HasZero K) (hε : 0 < ε) (hρ : 0 < ρ) :
    ∃ (s : Finset ((ι → ℝ) × ℝ)),
      (∀ p ∈ s, 2 * p.2 < ρ) ∧
      (∀ p ∈ s, (K ∩ Metric.closedBall p.1 p.2).Nonempty) ∧
      (K ⊆ ⋃ p ∈ s, Metric.closedBall p.1 p.2) ∧
      (∑ p in s, (2 * p.2) ^ Fintype.card ι < ε) := by
```

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• K has zero content, V(K) = 0 [tc_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any cube C that contains K, the Riemann integral of the characteristic function of K over C is zero: ∫_C ψ_K(X) dX = 0 [l1].

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• For any cube C containing K, ∫_C ψ_K(X) dX = 0 [l1].
• ϵ > 0 [tc_3].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For any cube C containing K, there exists a δ > 0 such that if P is any partition of C with norm ∥P∥ ≤ δ, then any Riemann sum σ of ψ_K over P satisfies 0 ≤ σ ≤ ϵ [l2].

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• P={C_1,…,C_k} is a partition of a cube C that contains K [def_1].
• The cubes are indexed such that C_j ∩ K ≠ ∅ for 1 ≤ j ≤ r and C_j ∩ K = ∅ for r+1 ≤ j ≤ k [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• K is a subset of the union of the first r cubes: K ⊂ ⋃_{j=1}^r C_j [l3].

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• The cubes of partition P are indexed such that C_j ∩ K = ∅ for j > r [def_2].
Therefore, we conclude:
• A Riemann sum σ = ∑_{j=1}^k ψ_K(X_j)V(C_j) over the partition P simplifies to σ = ∑_{j=1}^r ψ_K(X_j)V(C_j), because for j > r, any X_j ∈ C_j is not in K, making ψ_K(X_j) = 0 [l4].

Therefore, we conclude:
• There exists a specific Riemann sum σ (by choosing sample points X_j ∈ C_j ∩ K) which is equal to ∑_{j=1}^r V(C_j) [l5].

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• For the chosen partition P, its norm ∥P∥ < δ [def_1].
• For any partition with norm ≤ δ, any Riemann sum σ satisfies 0 ≤ σ ≤ ϵ [l2].
• There exists a particular Riemann sum σ equal to ∑_{j=1}^r V(C_j) [l5].
Therefore, we conclude:
• The sum of the volumes of the selected cubes is bounded by ϵ: ∑_{j=1}^r V(C_j) ≤ ϵ [l6].

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• A set of cubes {C_1, ..., C_r} is defined by selecting all cubes from a partition P that have a non-empty intersection with K [def_2].
• These cubes have edge lengths less than ρ [l7].
• The set K is contained in the union of these cubes, K ⊂ ⋃_{j=1}^r C_j [l3].
• The sum of the volumes of these cubes satisfies ∑_{j=1}^r V(C_j) ≤ ϵ [l6].
Therefore, we conclude:
• There exist cubes C_1, ..., C_r with edge lengths < ρ such that C_j ∩ K ≠ ∅ for 1 ≤ j ≤ r, K ⊂ ⋃_{j=1}^r C_j, and ∑_{j=1}^r V(C_j) ≤ ϵ, satisfying the theorem's conditions (with ≤ ϵ as proved) [ts_1].
